New Records: Rohit Sharma smashed eight sixes and seven fours, clearing the boundary over cover and mid-wicket with a mixture of brilliant timing and sheer power.
Rohit’s 19-ball 50 marked the fastest ever against Australia
Key Match Events: David Warner was dismissed in the first over of the chase for six, in what will be the veteran opener’s last international match if his team do not progress.
Mitch Marsh was superbly caught by a jumping Axar Patel on the boundary.
Glenn Maxwell was bowled by a Kuldeep Yadav wrong’un on 20.
Head was eventually caught trying to take on Jasprit Bumrah.
Australia lost 5-54 from the point when the equation was at 82 from eight.
Pre-Game Insights: There are no pre-game insights in the article.
Post-Match Reflections: There are no post-match reflections in the article.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The result means the undefeated India qualify for the semi-finals and will face England, while Australia’s hopes of being world champions in all formats are in grave danger.
A Bangladesh win would likely see Australia progress to face South Africa in the semi-finals, unless the Tigers are able to win by a significant margin and leapfrog Mitch Marsh’s men on net run-rate.
Others: Rohit took charge when he helped crunch 29 runs from the third over of the game off Mitchell Starc.
Josh Hazlewood was able to slow India down, appearing as if he was bowling on a different pitch with his 1-14 after removing Virat Kohli for a duck early.
